text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days.

text: Patient: When do you, when do you wanna start the trial? Doctor: You already got your scan. We start the biopsy. We go. No, no time wasted. Patient: Well I got – I got to do the biopsy? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile.

text: Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no?

text: Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. So it works on your testicles which produce the testosterone and it makes them stop producing testosterone. So people have like menopause type symptoms. Mm? Family Member: So you’re going to use Lupron? Doctor: Yes, exactly. Family Member: Mhm.

text: Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. The second reason is um having to do with your scans. We have the results of your bone scan and your um CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. And that is really the most important thing; so I wanted to say that first. The second one is the CAT scan. So on the CAT scan, you have a lymph node inside your abdomen - Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that- Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
